title: 113_s1823
content: The Act may be cited as the "Strengthening the Child Welfare Response to Human Trafficking Act of 2013". Best practices guidelines are established to combat trafficking of children. Within 1 year of the Act's enactment, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop guidelines to assist child welfare agencies and courts in serving youth victims of trafficking and those at risk. Consultation with various federal agencies will be conducted, and evidence-based models will be utilized in the guideline development. The guidelines developed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services will assist child welfare agencies and courts in serving youth victims of trafficking and those at risk. Input from various organizations will be included, and the guidelines will cover personnel resources and service delivery strategies for identifying and supporting victims. The guidelines aim to address the needs of foster youth who are victims of trafficking, emphasizing comprehensive, client-centered, trauma-informed strategies. Collaboration protocols between local agencies and non-profit organizations are crucial, including child welfare, medical professionals, law enforcement, and schools. Recommendations for safe residential placements and caregiver training are also highlighted. The curr_chunk provides sample protocols and recommended strategies for identifying and collecting data on trafficking victims, as well as preventing foster youth from becoming victims. It also suggests incorporating human trafficking designations in child welfare information systems. The curr_chunk focuses on streamlining data collection and reporting in the context of identifying and preventing human trafficking among foster youth. The curr_chunk amends the State Plan Requirements under the Foster Care and Adoption Assistance Program to include making reasonable efforts to identify and document child victims of trafficking. The curr_chunk amends the State Plan Requirements under the Foster Care and Adoption Assistance Program to include reporting child victims of trafficking to law enforcement agencies within 72 hours for entry into the National Crime Information Center database. The curr_chunk amends the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act to include provisions for the assessment and identification of trafficking victims, along with training and services for such victims. The curr_chunk adds a provision to the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act for identifying child trafficking victims. The curr_chunk adds a provision to the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act for identifying child trafficking victims. SEC. 4. REPORT TO THE CONGRESS. Within 18 months of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress outlining the prevalence of severe forms of trafficking in children under the care of child welfare agencies nationwide. The report should include details on sex trafficking and labor trafficking trends among these children. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The report will detail the prevalence of severe trafficking in children under the care of child welfare agencies nationwide, including sex and labor trafficking trends. The report will also list data specific to each State, Indian tribe, or tribal organization child welfare agency, summarize practices and protocols used to identify and serve child victims of trafficking, propose ongoing support and monitoring methods for agencies, and evaluate the feasibility of collecting annual or semiannual data from child welfare agencies. The report to Congress will evaluate the effects of proposed methods on child welfare agencies and specify necessary changes in law or regulation. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this Act will take effect one year after its enactment, with a possible delay if State legislation is required for compliance. The Act will take effect one year after enactment, with each year of a 2-year legislative session considered a separate regular session of the State legislature.
